The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. However, the existing axiomatizations are either incomplete or too technical to be of general interest. We provide a new axiomatization that is purely categorical and is accessible to a broad audience.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are thought to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. To understand the origin of the myxozoan body plan, we compared the genomes of two myxozoans to those of a free-living cnidarian and a parasitic cnidarian. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals, and that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the essential elements required for parasitism. Our findings suggest that the myxozoan transition was accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content.

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1. Our data reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune system and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, and maize is no exception. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values as the global mean temperature increases. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, many of which are on the brink of closure. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and they are concerned about accessing the CARES Act loans. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will be critical to the survival of many small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the action of a size-selective sink, which involves the fast fragmentation of plastic debris into smaller particles, their transfer to the ocean interior, and the subsequent accumulation of these particles in the deep ocean.

The origin of the solar system is still a matter of debate. One of the most important questions is the age of the solar system. The age of the solar system is determined by the age of the oldest objects in the solar system. The oldest objects in the solar system are presolar grains, which are formed in the cores of stars. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of animal societies. Here, we show that the evolution of sociality, in the form of domestication and allomaternal care, is associated with increased reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the amount of energy available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters. Finally, we show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the size of litters rather than an increase in the number of offspring produced. This suggests that the limiting factor in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder with a poor prognosis. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in the brain. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling blood pressure, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The communication network is critical for the endothelium to control these functions. Here, we show that the communication network is highly efficient and has a small-world configuration. This configuration is important for the endothelium to rapidly and efficiently integrate information from the environment and to coordinate the activities of the endothelium. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing therapies to control cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In response, we developed the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling is mediated by an allosteric mechanism, which is triggered by the opening of the activation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that a mutation at this position leads to the loss of C-type inactivation gating and to an inversion of the allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides a molecular understanding of the allosteric coupling in potassium channels and its implication for the design of potassium channel blockers. It also provides a molecular explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the K+ channel inhibitor, 4-aminopyridine.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic ecosystem that is constantly changing in response to the host's environment and diet. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is still being investigated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host's diet. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host's environment, and the host's environment is often influenced by the host's diet. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used by the host to influence the composition of the microbiome. This study provides a foundation for further investigation of the role of anaerobic fungi in the health of herbivores.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is due to a reduced probability to become dominant in a dyadic contest. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct properties. The synthesized structures are digitally designed and manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are then assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with specific behaviors under large deformations. The strategy can be further extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex behaviors under large deformations. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex behaviors under large deformations.

The hemoglobin pattern in human blood is a reflection of the developmental state of the hematopoietic system. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and can reverse the adult hemoglobin pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be involved in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we show that SREBP1-dependent monounsaturated fatty acids mediate ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may sensitize cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer patients with PI3K-mutated breast cancer or PTEN-defective prostate cancer. Hypertension is the most common risk factor for cardiovascular disease, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular medicine. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are widely used because of their efficacy and safety. However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which is mediated by the N terminus of the STIM protein. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but the recovery of these species has been slow. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral bird populations, which are associated with the loss of early-seral ecosystems. These findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. To combat this problem, we developed a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. We tested all compounds designed by us for their in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy is expected to be a valuable tool for the rational design of new antibiotics. The compounds designed by us are currently being evaluated in clinical trials. (PsycINFO Database Record

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the number of parameters increases exponentially with the depth of the network. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that is easier to train and apply. The proposed architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train than popular existing architectures.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. From

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are likely due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices, which has been shown experimentally to produce alerting effects, suppress melatonin, and phase-shift the biological clock. This study provides evidence that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime may have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. In this paper, we show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB samples is consistent with terrestrial sources. However, the osmium in the ejecta from an impact is likely to be of extraterrestrial origin.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, including lymphoproliferation, autoantibody production, and autoinflammatory disease. This was accompanied by a shift in the balance of Treg cells and a shift in the balance of Th17 cells.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk for AD. APOE is also a major protein of synapses, and APOE isoforms are known to regulate synaptic plasticity. Here, we show that APOE isoforms regulate the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also show that APOE4 is associated with increased accumulation of complement component 1q in AD brain, which may be due to defective astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may explain the differential risk of APOE4 for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely to occur than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well established, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving.

We show that the most accurate deep learning models for natural language processing also predict the neural and behavioral responses of the most accurate models of the language comprehension task. This suggests that the models are capturing the same, or at least similar, aspects of the underlying human mechanisms. We also show that the models’ neural fits and fits to the task performance are correlated with the architecture of the models. These results provide computational evidence that the models are capturing the same, or at least similar, aspects of the underlying human mechanisms. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the language comprehension system in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific computing problems. However, it is not clear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to approximate any function, or whether it is due to its instability. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a NN. This implies that the success of DL is not due to its ability to approximate any function, but rather due to its instability.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This failure is attributed to a classic experiment published 45 years ago. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study’s conclusion was widely accepted. Here, we discuss the flaws in the experiment and how they led to the erroneous conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We also discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition and the dissemination of psychological research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. In contrast, the pathogen associated with a reactional state known as lepromatous leprosy, M. lepromatosis, is a close relative of M. leprae. Here we present the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis and compare it with that of M. leprae. We find that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause peripheral neuropathy, whereas M. leprae has lost the ability to do so. Our findings suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This is important for understanding the evolution of the disease and the development of new treatments. (PsycINFO Database Record

Entanglement and entropy are the two main ingredients of the description of quantum states. They are also the two key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is therefore a key tool for the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid and large-scale vaccination program. To achieve this, a vaccine must be safe, effective, and easy to manufacture. Here, we describe a vaccine that is safe, effective, and easy to manufacture. This is the first time that a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine has been described.

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks, which have been associated with the spread of rats or fleas. However, the role of fleas in the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) has been controversial. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for understanding the role of ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic of interest to neuroscientists and cognitive scientists. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is not only different from that of brain size but also different from one lineage to another. We also show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is associated with the evolution of cognitive ability. These findings have important implications for the study of the evolution of brain function.

The molecular chaperone TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the other member of the HSP90 chaperone family. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The process of disassembly is controlled by a family of proteins called actin depolymerizing factors (ADF)/cofilins. ADF/cofilins are the central regulators of actin filament disassembly. They are responsible for severing actin filaments. However, how they do so is not known. Here, we show that ADF/cofilins sever actin filaments by inducing a mechanical torque. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilins in cells and for designing new strategies to control actin dynamics.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in foods and beverages. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related metabolic disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island has been colonized by both Southeast Asians and Africans. The colonization was not homogeneous across the island, and the genetic structure is also not homogeneous. These results suggest that the island was colonized by multiple waves of migration, and that the genetic structure is the result of a combination of admixture and demographic growth. The results also suggest that the island has been colonized recently, and that the island has been under the influence of the African climate for a few centuries. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. They also have implications for understanding the genetic diversity of the world.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that are important for translation. In this study, we show that the presence of a chemical modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in messenger RNA can have a modest impact on translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can alter both the rate of translation and the rate of protein synthesis. This study provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on the ribosome and protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and more time spent in social activities and exercising. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, educational attainment, and health status. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining characteristic of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The common cold is caused by rhinoviruses, which replicate more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To gain insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibited a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C, which correlated with significantly higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the temperature-dependent growth of rhinoviruses and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria sense their environment using a variety of sensors. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the surface on which it is growing. This mechanism is important for the pathogen because it allows it to sense the presence of a surface and to respond to it by increasing the activity of its type IV pili, which in turn promotes the attachment of the bacterium to the surface. This attachment, in turn, can stimulate the production of additional virulence factors. Our findings thus demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates the attachment of the bacterium to a surface. This is an important discovery because it shows that bacteria can use the mechanical activity of their surface adhesins to sense the environment. This is a fundamental process that is important for bacterial adaptation and pathogenicity. (Show more)

The presence of pesticides in surface water is a global concern. However, the extent of pesticide contamination in surface water is still poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide contamination in surface water. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the presence of particularly toxic pesticides is even more widespread. This study highlights the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the potential for SARS-CoV-2 to persist in wildlife reservoirs and spread to other animal species and humans remains unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer and could be a source of human and animal infections. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will require a One Health approach to monitor and mitigate the spread of the virus. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

The amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the major component of senile plaques and is considered the main culprit in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). However, the immune response in the brain is complex and involves a variety of cell types. Here, we show that neurons are also involved in the immune response in AD, and that they are the source of cytokines that trigger the immune system. This is an important finding, since it suggests that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may trigger an immune response that may lead to neuronal death. This may be a significant factor in the development of AD.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. Here we present evidence that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is difficult to understand the folding mechanism from the results of a single experiment. Here we show that the folding of a large protein can be studied in great detail by combining hydrogen exchange with mass spectrometry. We show that the folding of maltose binding protein has distinct steps, and that the steps are adjacent in the native protein. This study adds a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress, and their decapping is critical for the rapid degradation of their RNA substrates. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decape Np4-capped RNAs, also decaps those RNAs in a manner distinct from the one it uses to decape other RNAs. This enzyme prefers Np4-capped RNAs as substrates, but, unlike ApaH, it does not remove the capping group. Instead, it cleaves the RNA at a unique site, generating a monophosphorylated RNA 5′ terminus that must be further deprotected by a second enzyme to initiate RNA degradation. This unique manner of decapping Np4-capped RNAs could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is activated in response to sepsis, it is also impaired, leading to a vicious cycle of immunosuppression and organ dysfunction. In this study, we show that arginine, an essential amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that its deficiency contributes to the development of immunosuppressive cells. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is able to restore T cell function and proliferation, decrease the expansion of immunosuppressive cells, and improve the clinical outcome of sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a reference for future studies on the biomass of other complex systems.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a paradigm in physics, biology, and computer science. SOC is characterized by the following properties: (i) the system is in a critical state, (ii) the system is self-regulating, and (iii) the system is critical in the sense that the rate of change of the system is proportional to the value of the system. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior.

Here, we show that strain engineering can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We show that strain can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We show that strain can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is still elusive. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula. This peptide is highly diverse and exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We show that this peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and that it is able to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane, and induce reactive oxygen species in germlings. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this peptide and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is an important step towards the development of sustainable agriculture. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions are enriched for proteins involved in energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of Drosophila sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease (VWD), a disorder of VWF function. The mechanism is also important for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF. The mechanism is also important for understanding the effects of flow on VWF function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and uses it to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and diseases. The results of this study will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI is complex and difficult to be observed. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties simultaneously. The observations show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path, but it does affect the cloud droplet number concentration and effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is inferred to be ∼15 °C, but the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is unknown. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

The pore gates of ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may help us understand the mechanism of the BK channel’s unique properties. They may also provide a new approach to drug development for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure. (Read more)

The malaria parasite invades the human erythrocyte, where it replicates and causes disease. The invasion process is a complex interaction between parasite and host cell, and the role of the erythrocyte in the process is poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the erythrocyte, increasing the cytoskeletal tension and reducing the bending modulus of the membrane. These changes are correlated with the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite primes the erythrocyte surface, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is an important step in understanding the invasion process and the development of new strategies for malaria control. (Show more)

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome. Our findings may have implications for the development of strategies to mitigate influenza virus infection and disease. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain implements a bottom-up parser that compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This parser may be a key component of the brain’s language processing system. (PsycINFO Database Record

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway in development and homeostasis. It is important to understand the regulation of the pathway to understand the development of disease. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the midbrain. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key goal of synthetic biology. Here, we demonstrate the ability to control the nitrogen cycle in a plant–bacterial symbiosis, using a synthetic circuit to control the expression of the nitrogenase enzyme in a diazotrophic bacterium. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for controlling the nitrogen cycle in a plant–bacterial symbiosis. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of synthetic biology and agriculture.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to inform forest monitoring and management, but the alerts are often too late to prevent deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect the presence and location of sound sources in their environment. The hearing organs of animals are all part of the body of the animal, and the size of the hearing organ is constrained by the size of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider can hear without a body because its web is a highly sensitive acoustic sensor.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the combined effects of fossil-fuel-related emissions and anthropogenic aerosols on global climate and human health are not. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The lack of a global vaccine supply is a major impediment to controlling the pandemic. Here we report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is well-suited for presentation on a virus-like particle (VLP). The engineered RBD variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD variant may be a promising candidate for a global vaccine supply. (Show more)

The role of the ALK receptor in development and disease is well established. However, the ligand(s) for human ALK are still unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like proteins (DrALKals) are ligands for human ALK. We further show that DrALKals are involved in zebrafish neural crest development. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALK-like proteins in vertebrate development. This is an important step towards understanding the function of ALK-like proteins in human disease.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a topic of great interest. However, the history of plague is poorly understood due to the lack of ancient DNA evidence. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that plague was already a highly diverse pathogen during this period, and that the emergence of plague as a disease was a gradual process that took place over millennia. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical issue for the sustainability of global food production. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive losses of SOC. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in reversing this trend is unknown. We show that soil health management practices that maintain or increase crop diversity, reduce soil disturbance, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC in the most stable fraction of soil organic matter. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to assess the risk of spillover and spread of viruses in animals to humans. We then applied this framework to a large dataset of viruses from wildlife and found that the top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic pathogens. We created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the risk of spillover and spread of viruses in animals to humans. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a valuable resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the blood-red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a highly favored trait and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the genetic history of the European population during the period of cultural change is not fully understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a panel of 41 individuals from southern Germany, including 11 women. Our data indicate that women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results establish DPP4 as a functional

The emergence of zoonotic pathogens, such as COVID-19, necessitates rapid and accurate pathogen identification. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a powerful tool for pathogen identification, but its application is limited by the need for bioinformatics and laboratory capacity. Here, we demonstrate the feasibility of mNGS in a resource-scarce setting, where the burden of febrile illness is high. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the potential of mNGS in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of DNA strands in the 3′ to 5′ direction. This process is catalyzed by DNA polymerases, which are essential for the maintenance of genome integrity. In humans, DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template and anchors to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp to form a holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. Here, we show that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the mechanism of human lagging strand replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA ribozymes, but the process is inefficient and the resulting molecules are of low quality. Here, we report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that improved the activity and generality of an RNA polymerase ribozyme. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also toxic at high concentrations. The ability to control copper levels is therefore critical for the survival of fungi. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis. The xan cluster is also expressed in other filamentous fungi, suggesting that this mechanism of copper homeostasis may be widespread in fungi. The ability of xan BGC metabolites to bind copper and impact cellular copper content may have implications for the control of fungal infections. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the control of fungal infections. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a high-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2 that is only stable at temperatures >870 °C and pressures >1.5 GPa. The presence of this mineral in a sedimentary rock suggests that the sediment source region was at high temperature and pressure, and that the sediment was deposited at a depth of >100 m. The sedimentary environment is consistent with a “Lake Gale” catchment environment.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, and the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly linked to the evolutionary history of the species involved. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether these cells are pathogenic or merely part of the immune response. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which is unable to induce colitis in a transfer model. This subset is dependent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet, which is required for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells can be divided into two functionally distinct subsets, one of which is pathogenic. This has important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is unknown. Here we report a method to convert human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease mechanism and test potential therapies. We show that astrocytes derived from ALS patients are toxic to motor neurons, suggesting a common mechanism. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. It will also allow us to study the disease mechanism in human cells. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays an important role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of Anaplasma in the tick. We demonstrate that the protein binds the d-alanine terminus of bacterial peptidoglycan, which alters the permeability of the gut and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic evolutionary transitions in the history of life. The discovery of a basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of its components. In this paper, we show that the behavior of the stratospheric water vapor component is important for the climate system.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of color patterns to avoid predation and to blend in with their surroundings. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green coloration in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the underlying mechanism is the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We describe these proteins, which we name biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs), and show that they are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We also provide a molecular explanation for the evolution of green coloration in anurans. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to form cancer stem cells (CSCs) is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces breast cancer cells to produce a protein called AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and it is required for the ability of breast cancer cells to form cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost transparent. The source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method using standard conservation treatments to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of extinction and recovery. Here we present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery interval at the base of the Triassic.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the first line of defense against invading pathogens and the main site of nutrient absorption. Therefore, intestinal homeostasis is essential for the survival of the host. However, intestinal inflammation is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common mutation in the spike protein of currently circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses. We show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. This may explain the higher transmissibility of D614G mutants. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may not be as detrimental to virus infectivity as previously thought. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites.
