The chemical behavior of matter is a key ingredient in understanding the origin of the universe and the origin of life. The chemical behavior of matter is also a key ingredient in understanding the origin of the Earth and the origin of life on the Earth. In this work, we show that the chemical behavior of matter is also a key ingredient in understanding the origin of the universe.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can affect the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are complex and depend on the strength of feedbacks between fire and the carbon cycle. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a strong influence on the trajectory of fire activity, and that these feedbacks can reduce or enhance warming. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowing global warming, but that the risk of more extreme fires may offset some of these benefits. Our study highlights the importance of human ignitions in shaping the future of fire regimes and the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and health of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, which is metabolized by the bacteria to enhance their ability to survive in a specific habitat. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is producing light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how animals can regulate the activities of their symbionts. It also suggests that other animals may use similar strategies to control the activities of their own symbionts. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is motivated by the need to understand the gendered nature of violent death narratives. We show that our method can identify topics that are not captured by existing structured variables and can identify the gender bias of topics. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains, including medical records, social media, and news. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data and can be applied to a wide range of domains.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. (Show more)

Asteroids are a well-known cause of mass mortality events in marine ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, a densovirus (Parvoviridae) has recently been linked to a disease that causes rapid degradation of the host. Here, we show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease and that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. This study provides evidence that a virus can cause a mass mortality event in a marine ecosystem and that it is possible to predict the presence of a virus in a marine ecosystem based on its historical presence. This is important for the management of marine ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of specific targets for therapy is a major challenge. Here we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that the antibodies are capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the data suggest that the antibodies are capable of being used in combination with other therapies. This would be an important step forward in the treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island has been colonized by both Southeast Asians and Africans. The colonization was not homogeneous across the island, and the genetic structure is also not homogeneous. The genetic structure is also influenced by geography, suggesting that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genetic diversity of Madagascar, and it will be useful for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It will also be useful for understanding the genetic diversity of Southeast Asia and Africa. (Show more)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. In some cases, the RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a protein encoded by the RNA. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with a membrane-associated enzyme and increases its activity. The RNA also base pairs with two other RNAs, repressing their expression. We show that the protein interferes with the ability of the other RNAs to repress the expression of the genes. This is an example of a protein that interferes with the ability of an RNA to regulate its own gene. This is an example of a protein that interferes with the ability of an RNA to regulate its own gene.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting crop condition index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be applied to other agricultural commodities and countries.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory in the brain. We show that the activity of single neurons can be used to write information into a dynamic memory register that can be read back out for processing. This mechanism is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons, and it is sensitive to context and serial order. We demonstrate that this mechanism can support memory span and the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the study of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of the plant kingdom. Here, we show that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the macroevolutionary state of the host plant. We demonstrate that the transition to parasitic lifestyles is linked to a relaxation of purifying selection, which is accompanied by bursts of gene loss. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was caused by a combination of natural variability and anthropogenic climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. This increase is expected to continue under high-emission scenarios, with the probability of a multiyear rainfall deficit in SSA increasing from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100. This study highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. It also demonstrates the importance of using high-resolution models to assess the impact of anthropogenic climate change on regional drought risk. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which these materials are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a unique link between the formation of the material and the date of the explosion.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of chemical energy on Earth. The capture of solar energy is accomplished by chlorophyll, a tetrapyrrole pigment. The conversion of light energy to chemical energy is catalyzed by a series of proteins that modify chlorophyll. The formation of the fifth ring of chlorophyll, the isocyclic isoprenoid ring, is a key reaction in this series. The mechanism of this reaction has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. Here we show that the formation of the isoprenoid ring of chlorophyll is catalyzed by three different enzymes in different photosynthetic lineages. These data provide a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of the isoprenoid ring of chlorophyll. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in recent decades, and that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. This finding has important implications for the future of California, which is expected to warm substantially over the next few decades.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the core autistic symptoms and suggests a potential therapeutic target for autism. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In the process, it offers a more nuanced understanding of the role of negativity biases in shaping the news media.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of intracellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the STIM1 protein that lead to constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, resulting in bleeding and thrombocytopenia. We also identify mutations in the ORAI1 protein that lead to a similar phenotype. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates, which is in turn dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous and that the release of aggregates is dependent on fusion protein 1. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX (myotis pilosus submandibular protein), selectively inhibits the leukotriene-A4 hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase to inhibit leukotriene B4 generation, which is a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential explanation for the origin of the influenza virus pandemic in 1918. The pandemic was caused by a reassortment of a bat-borne influenza virus with a human-borne virus. The bat-borne virus was likely infected by the human-borne virus through the immune privilege of the submandibular salivary gland. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a small molecule that inhibits both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). This dual inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that a cancer cell-line screen reveals that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. We further show that formate, a one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). We demonstrate that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These studies provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for cancer. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. However, the proteins that form inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the unique cellular environment of motor neurons, which are exposed to a variety of stresses that may contribute to the formation of inclusion bodies. This study provides a molecular explanation for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device can also be used for quantum information processing. The device is scalable to larger dimensions and can be used for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device can also be used for quantum information processing.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a better understanding of the early evolution of the flowering plants. Montsechia is a plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is an important plant for understanding the early evolution of the flowering plants because it is an aquatic plant that lived in a very early stage of angiosperm evolution.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) and show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we find a substitution rate that is an order of magnitude lower than inferred previously. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising globally at a rate of about 2.9 mm/y over the last 25 y. This rate is expected to continue for decades to come. However, the rate of acceleration of sea level over the last 25 y is not constant. We find that the rate of acceleration is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, which implies that the rate of sea level rise could accelerate even more in the future. This could have significant implications for coastal infrastructure and the environment.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase is greater for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. It is consistent with a more general erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and it has important implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a key reaction of tryptophan synthase. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. In this study, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This study supports the need for further investigation of remdesivir in a clinical trial setting. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, which is metabolized by the bacteria to enhance their ability to survive in a specific habitat. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is producing light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. It also suggests that other animals may use similar strategies to control the activities of their symbionts. (Show more)

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools by changing the way teachers think about students. We show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and that these mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of school discipline, which is a major source of inequality in the criminal justice system.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large proportion of obesity and diet-related disease. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a significant impact on meal selection behavior. This has the potential to contribute to both environmental and health goals.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and is the site of many important cellular processes. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry-based approaches to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is formed by a unique sequence in ORF8 that is not present in SARS-CoV. The structure also reveals a second interface that is not present in SARS-CoV, which may be important for immune evasion. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the spread of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis in cultured cortical neurons. We also show that the development of edema is associated with the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful for the treatment of cerebral edema. The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been selected for its potential to reveal strong associations. The strength of an association is assessed by setting a higher threshold for declaring significance. This is a challenge in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We also discuss the implications of selective inference for the interpretation of results from complex statistical models.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of vascular ECs is difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we report the generation of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new strategy for the development of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of a new treatment for vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be extended to the generation of vascular ECs for the development of vascular networks in regenerative medicine. This study may also provide a new strategy for the development of vascular ECs.

The discovery of ligand-activated RTKs has revolutionized our understanding of the complexity of the signaling network. In this study, we show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands for the orphan RTKs Alk and Ltk. We demonstrate that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores and the pigmentation of the adult body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigmentation of the adult body. This study provides a foundation for further exploration of the function of Alk and Ltk in the context of their physiological ligands. (Show more)

β-Cell dysfunction is one of the main molecular bases for type 2 diabetes (T2D). In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO β-cells. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most pathogenic human viruses. They are divided into subtypes, which are further divided into lineages. The evolution of these lineages is not well understood. Here, we show that the interaction between two viral RNA segments is sequence specific and can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide a molecular explanation for the evolution of influenza A viruses. They also suggest that this interaction could be a target for antiviral drug development. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and smoking. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including the local hemodynamic environment. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a significant threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to carbon emissions. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results suggest that actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host may play an important role. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus is cleared from the host within 5 d, and that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by 2 d. We also show that the treatment should be given as soon as possible after infection to be effective. These results can help guide the development of treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is caused by the thermal stress-induced loss of the symbiotic zooxanthellae. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the catabolic degradation of amino acids is a key process that contributes to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. This process is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress, which in turn is a consequence of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse, and many die from the disease. In this study, we show that the activation of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize, to survive treatment with chemotherapy, and to form tumors in mice. We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a matter of debate. Here we show that the start of accelerated deglaciation at ∼17.7 ka coincides with the start of extensive volcanic eruptions from Mount Takahe, Antarctica. The eruptions are unprecedented in the last 20,000 y, and the volcanic ash is found in ice cores >2,800 km away. The eruptions are also unique in that they led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly explains the changes in climate and ocean circulation in the Southern Hemisphere.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from rivers with high levels of human stress and biodiversity loss. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the high dependence of poor and hungry populations on inland fisheries makes them vulnerable to the impacts of fishing on biodiversity and food security. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries management is needed to protect biodiversity and food security. They can also be used to identify areas where fisheries management is needed to protect biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical signaling pathways that mediate regeneration in the adult Drosophila and Caenorhabditis elegans nervous systems. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is enhanced by reducing neuronal activity and elevating cAMP. These findings suggest that the mechanisms that control endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon growth in the same neuron type are also involved in the control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This study unites disparate forms of neuronal outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. (Show more)

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, but the rate of recombination between homologous chromosomes is a major determinant of the speed of meiosis. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination rates in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. We also find that recombination rates are higher in the promoter regions of genes, and that the distribution of recombination rates is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice. These results suggest that the distribution of recombination rates in plants may be a conserved feature of the eukaryotic genome.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis suggests that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each with its own characteristic pattern of activity. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been difficult to interpret because of the large number of networks that are activated during rest. Here, we show that metabolic imaging, which measures the total activity of the brain, can be used to identify and validate the RSNs. We also show that the RSNs are altered in Parkinson’s disease, and that this alteration can be corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct link between the functional and metabolic properties of the brain. It also suggests that metabolic imaging can be used to monitor the progression of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). It is essential for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We propose that this modification may have a role in modulating mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We investigated whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in blood are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) persist at certain loci associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Our findings also suggest that epigenetic modifications may be a potential target for the treatment of diabetes complications. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. (PsycINFO Database Record

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic relapsing disorder with a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the development of psychological symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for studying the evolution of fruit flavor, and the study of its volatile components is a major focus of research. The biosynthesis of these volatile compounds is largely unknown, and the identification of the genes involved in their production is a major goal of the field. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the production of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and suggest that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning may be greater than previously thought. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a variety of cell types that encode information about the local environment and the direction of the animal’s head. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which encode the animal’s position in space, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings have implications for understanding the organization of the MEC and the neural basis of navigation. They also suggest that the MEC may be a good target for neurostimulation to treat navigational disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. In many plants, flowering is induced by the accumulation of the flowering repressor FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT). However, in some parasitic plants, flowering is induced by a different mechanism. Here, we show that the flowering repressor FT is able to induce flowering in its parasitic relatives. This study demonstrates that the flowering process is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that dopamine-containing neurons in the nigro system, which is the classic pathway of dopamine release in the brain, form specialized integrative units within the system. These units, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomes, dopamine-containing dendrites, and other neurons and fibers. The striosome–dendron bouquets are likely critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we are? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We show that this signal is used by others to assess connection, and that it is used by others to assess connection, and that it is used by others to assess connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly coordinated network of cells that adjusts heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and that its deletion in mice leads to a reduction in the number of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores in these cells. This leads to a reduction in the electrical activity of the SAN, as is evident by a reduction in heart rate and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a key regulator of Ca2+ stores in SAN cells and contributes to the electrical activity of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated for decades. In addition, the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway plays a crucial role in mediating antiherbivore defense responses in plants. However, the interaction between Si and JA in response to insect attack has not been examined directly. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment increases rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in RNAi lines of allene oxide synthase and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1. Additionally, Si pretreatment promotes Si accumulation and enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder. These results suggest a strong interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores involving priming of JA-mediated defense responses by Si and the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis is important for the lipidome of murine macrophages and that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be supported by sustained, elevated neural activity. However, there is also evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation may play a role in memory. Here we propose a mechanism that combines the two. We show that information can be stored in the form of adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. These changes in conductances can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical challenge for the development of plant-based therapeutics. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and provides a detailed assessment of the design parameters for plant cell internalization and corresponding gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and synthetic biology communities. (Show more)

Nutrient inputs to lakes and reservoirs are often dominated by small tributaries, but their importance has been largely overlooked. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, the remaining 235 tributaries are responsible for the majority of the nutrients that are dissolved and available for uptake by algae. This study reveals that small tributaries may be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, and that nutrient management efforts should consider the role of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication. Our findings have important implications for the management of nutrient inputs to lakes and reservoirs worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by rare combinations of forces.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We also show that the same parameter fluctuations in the microcircuitry of the brain can be tolerated in an in silico model of the control condition, but that these same parameter fluctuations can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the presence of NMDAR-Abs. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that NMDAR-Abs may be able to cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities even in the absence of neuronal injury. This may be important for understanding the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs and the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The history of abrupt climate change is a key topic in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the lack of data and models that can capture the full complexity of the Earth system. Here, we present a study that combines a multiproxy approach with Earth system modeling to investigate an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. The event was also linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. Our study provides a new perspective on the history of abrupt climate change. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is a major driver of deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer of the commodity. In response, many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In plants, the exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of vacuolar trafficking. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex in plants is still unknown. Here, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potential drug target for human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles are segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. In this study, we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles, one of which determines sex, also determines the sex of the gonad. We find that polygenic sex determination produces modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a unique tissue in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptor cells and by the pigment epithelium, respectively. The latter is also challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by ROS. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which is a key ROS source, impact the photoreceptor/pigment epithelium redox balance. We also show that the levels of iron impact the degradation of bisretinoids, which is a major contributor to the loss of photoreceptor cell viability. These findings have implications for the treatment of retinal degeneration. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end. Here we show that specialization can be maintained and even enhanced by morphological evolution. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The study of the hominin hand fossil record has been limited by the paucity of fossils from the time interval between 800,000 and 1.8 My ago, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. Here we show that a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, was present ∼1.42 My ago in a fossil from Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study thus provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a small molecule that inhibits both human SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that this dual inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in colon cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These findings provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. They also provide a metabolic rationale for the use of formate as a cancer therapeutic. (Read more)

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely appreciated. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. This approach can be used to understand the impact of other environmental changes on people’s diets. This is an important step in understanding the complex interactions between people and their environments.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the increase in subsoil compaction risk is a consequence of the increasing size of modern farm machinery, which is now approaching the weight of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods.
